title: What is DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS is software used to store, organize, retrieve and manage data. It provides security, concurrency, backup and data integrity. Examples: MySQL, Oracle, PostgreSQL.

title: What are the advantages of DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS provides data security, reduces redundancy, improves data consistency, supports backup and recovery, allows concurrent access, and offers fast data retrieval using indexes.

title: Difference between DBMS and RDBMS
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS stores data as files and does not support relationships. RDBMS stores data in tables and supports relationships using primary and foreign keys, ensuring integrity.

title: Types of DBMS
subject: DBMS
answer: Major DBMS types: Hierarchical, Network, Relational (RDBMS), Object-Oriented DBMS.

title: What is a relation?
subject: DBMS
answer: A relation is a table consisting of rows and columns. Each row is a record and each column is an attribute.

title: What is a table?
subject: DBMS
answer: A table is a structured collection of rows and columns used to store data in a relational database.

title: What are rows and columns?
subject: DBMS
answer: Rows (tuples) represent records. Columns (attributes) represent properties of the data and have specific data types.

title: Primary components of DBMS
subject: DBMS
answer: Main components: Database engine, schema, query processor, transaction manager and storage manager.

title: What is a primary key?
subject: DBMS
answer: A primary key uniquely identifies each row in a table. It cannot be NULL and must be unique.

title: What is a foreign key?
subject: DBMS
answer: A foreign key is a column that refers to the primary key of another table, creating a relationship between tables.

title: What is normalization?
subject: DBMS
answer: Normalization organizes data to reduce redundancy and avoid anomalies while improving consistency.

title: What is denormalization?
subject: DBMS
answer: Denormalization intentionally adds redundancy to improve query performance in read-heavy systems.

title: What is a candidate key?
subject: DBMS
answer: A candidate key is any attribute or set of attributes that can uniquely identify a row. One candidate becomes the primary key.

title: What is the SELECT statement used for?
subject: DBMS
answer: SELECT retrieves data from tables. Example: SELECT name FROM student WHERE age > 18;

title: What is a view?
subject: DBMS
answer: A view is a virtual table created from a query. It does not store data physically but displays data from base tables.

title: What are the types of relationships in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: Main relationships are: One-to-One, One-to-Many and Many-to-Many.

title: What is a schema in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: A schema defines the structure of the database, including tables, columns, relationships and constraints.

title: What are constraints in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: Constraints are rules applied to table columns to maintain data integrity. Examples: NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, UNIQUE, CHECK, DEFAULT.

title: Difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE
subject: DBMS
answer: DELETE removes selected rows and can be rolled back. TRUNCATE removes all rows quickly, does not log each row and usually cannot be rolled back.

title: What is an index in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: An index is a data structure that speeds up search and retrieval by storing references to rows based on column values.

title: Who is a Database Administrator (DBA)?
subject: DBMS
answer: A DBA manages database design, backups, security, performance tuning, upgrades and troubleshooting.

title: What is an ER diagram?
subject: DBMS
answer: An ER diagram visually shows entities, attributes and relationships used to design a database.

title: What is a JOIN in SQL?
subject: DBMS
answer: A JOIN combines rows from multiple tables using related columns. Types: INNER, LEFT, RIGHT, FULL, CROSS and SELF JOIN.

title: What is a subquery?
subject: DBMS
answer: A subquery is a query written inside another query, often used to filter results. Example: SELECT name FROM student WHERE age > (SELECT AVG(age) FROM student);

title: What are aggregate functions?
subject: DBMS
answer: Aggregate functions operate on groups of rows and return one value. Examples: COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN.

title: What is a transaction in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: A transaction is a sequence of operations executed as a single logical unit that ensures the database remains consistent.

title: What is ACID in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation and Durability — properties that guarantee reliable transactions.

title: What is a stored procedure?
subject: DBMS
answer: A stored procedure is a pre-compiled set of SQL statements stored in the database that can be executed repeatedly.

title: What is a trigger?
subject: DBMS
answer: A trigger automatically executes when an INSERT, UPDATE or DELETE occurs on a table, often used to enforce rules or logging.

title: Difference between UNION and UNION ALL
subject: DBMS
answer: UNION removes duplicates from combined results. UNION ALL keeps duplicates and is faster.

title: What is indexing in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: Indexing speeds up data retrieval by creating a separate structure that stores key values with pointers to actual rows.

title: What are normal forms in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: Normal forms are rules to reduce redundancy: 1NF removes repeating groups, 2NF removes partial dependency, 3NF removes transitive dependency and BCNF is stricter.

title: Difference between INNER JOIN and OUTER JOIN
subject: DBMS
answer: INNER JOIN returns only matching records. OUTER JOIN returns matching records plus non-matching rows with NULL values.

title: What is data redundancy?
subject: DBMS
answer: Data redundancy is unnecessary duplication of data, which can be reduced using normalization and constraints.

title: What is a deadlock?
subject: DBMS
answer: Deadlock occurs when two transactions wait on each other for resources, preventing both from proceeding.

title: What is a database cursor?
subject: DBMS
answer: A cursor allows row-by-row processing of a result set when operations cannot be done in a single query.

title: Types of database locks
subject: DBMS
answer: Common locks: Shared (read), Exclusive (write), Intent locks and Update locks to manage concurrent access.

title: Difference between clustered and non-clustered index
subject: DBMS
answer: Clustered index rearranges table data physically and there can be one per table. Non-clustered index stores separate pointers and multiple can exist.

title: Importance of COMMIT and ROLLBACK
subject: DBMS
answer: COMMIT saves transaction changes permanently. ROLLBACK undoes uncommitted changes, restoring the database state.

title: Difference between super key and candidate key
subject: DBMS
answer: Super key uniquely identifies records but may contain extra attributes. Candidate key is minimal — no unnecessary attributes.

title: Types of constraints in DBMS
subject: DBMS
answer: Common constraints: NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, UNIQUE, CHECK and DEFAULT.

title: Difference between primary key and unique key
subject: DBMS
answer: Primary key is unique and NOT NULL, one per table. Unique key allows NULL values and a table can have multiple unique keys.

title: What is referential integrity?
subject: DBMS
answer: Referential integrity ensures foreign key values always reference valid records, preventing orphan rows.

title: How does DBMS handle concurrency control?
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS uses locking, timestamp ordering, optimistic control and two-phase locking to avoid conflicts and maintain consistency.

title: Advantages of foreign keys
subject: DBMS
answer: Foreign keys maintain relationships, enforce integrity, support cascading updates/deletes and improve meaningful queries.

title: What is a transaction log?
subject: DBMS
answer: A transaction log records all database operations, allowing recovery in case of failure and helping maintain consistency.

title: What is a materialized view?
subject: DBMS
answer: A materialized view stores the result of a query physically, improving performance for repeated read operations.

title: Difference between ER diagram and relational schema
subject: DBMS
answer: ER diagram models data conceptually using entities and relationships. Relational schema defines physical tables, columns and constraints.

title: What is GROUP BY in SQL?
subject: DBMS
answer: GROUP BY groups rows based on column values and is often used with aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM and AVG.

title: What is a stored function?
subject: DBMS
answer: A stored function is similar to a procedure but must return a value and can be used inside SQL expressions.

title: What are different normalization techniques?
subject: DBMS
answer: Normalization forms: 1NF removes repeating groups, 2NF removes partial dependency, 3NF removes transitive dependency and BCNF ensures every determinant is a candidate key.

title: What are the phases of query processing?
subject: DBMS
answer: Query processing includes parsing, translation, optimization and execution.

title: What are the types of database backups?
subject: DBMS
answer: Types include full backup, incremental backup, differential backup and transaction log backups.

title: What is WITH CHECK OPTION in views?
subject: DBMS
answer: WITH CHECK OPTION ensures that inserted or updated rows through a view must satisfy the view's condition.

title: Explain B-Tree and B+ Tree
subject: DBMS
answer: B-Tree stores keys and data in internal nodes. B+ Tree stores data only in leaf nodes with linked leaves for faster range queries.

title: What is hashing in DBMS?
subject: DBMS
answer: Hashing maps data to buckets using a hash function, enabling very fast searching.

title: Difference between trigger and stored procedure
subject: DBMS
answer: Triggers execute automatically on events like insert/update. Stored procedures are executed manually and can take parameters.

title: What is data partitioning?
subject: DBMS
answer: Partitioning splits large tables into smaller parts to improve performance, manageability and availability.

title: How does DBMS ensure security and integrity?
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS enforces security through authentication, authorization, encryption and constraints to maintain integrity.

title: Difference between DBMS and file-based system
subject: DBMS
answer: DBMS stores structured data with relationships, supports transactions, security and backup. File systems lack relationships, integrity control and concurrency management.
